Vqdd73C2.title: Potential-Dependent Generation of O2– and LiO2 and Their Critical Roles in O2 Reduction to Li2O2 in Aprotic Li–O2 Batteries
Vqdd73C2.abstract: Discharging of the aprotic Li–O2 battery relies on the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) producing Li2O2 in the positive electrode, which remains incompletely understood. Here, we report a mechanistic study of the Li-ORR on a model system, i.e., an Au electrode in a Li+ dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) electrolyte. By spectroscopic identification of the reaction intermediates coupled with density functional theory calculations, we conclude that the formation of O2– and LiO2 in the Li-ORR critically depends on electrode potentials and determines the Li2O2 formation mechanism. At low overpotentials (u003e 2.0 V vs Li/Li+) O2– is identified to be the first surface intermediate, which diffuses into the bulk electrolyte and forms Li2O2 therein via a solution-mediated disproportionation mechanism. At high overpotentials (ca. 2.0–1.6 V vs Li/Li+) LiO2 has been observed, which can rapidly transform to Li2O2 by further electro-reduction, suggesting a surface-mediated mechanism. The solution-mediated Li2O2 formation that can ac...

k7NUtK7y.title: Tibet's Ali: A New Window to Detect the CMB Polarization
k7NUtK7y.abstract: The Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) Polarization plays an important role in current cosmological studies. CMB B-mode polarization is the most effective probe to primordial gravitational waves (PGWs) and a test of the inflation as well as other theories of the early universe such as bouncing and cyclic universe. So far, major ground-based CMB polarization experiments are located in the southern hemisphere.Recently, China has launched the Ali CMB Polarization Telescope (AliCPT) in Tibetan Plateau to measure CMB B mode polarization and detect the PGWs in northern hemisphere. AliCPT include two stages, the first one is to build a telescope at the 5250m site (AliCPT-1) and the second one is to have a more sensitive telescope at a higher altitude of about 6000m (AliCPT-2). In this paper, we report the atmospherical conditions, sky coverage and the current infrastructure associated with AliCPT. We analyzed the reanalysis data from MERRA-2 together with radiosonde data from the Ali Meteorological Service and found that the amount of water vapor has a heavy seasonal variation and October to March is the suitable observation time. We also found 95/150 GHz to be feasible for AliCPT-1 and higher frequencies to be possible for AliCPT-2. Then we analyzed the observable sky and the target fields, and showed that Ali provides us a unique opportunity to observe CMB with less foreground contamination in the northern hemisphere and is complementary to the existed southern CMB experiments. Together with the developed infrastructure, we point out that Ali opens a new window for CMB observation and will be one of the major sites in the world along with Antarctic and Atacama.
k7NUtK7y.venue: arXiv: Instrumentation and Methods for Astrophysics

R12TuoQo.title: Amorphous Li2 O2 : Chemical Synthesis and Electrochemical Properties.
R12TuoQo.abstract: When aprotic Li–O2 batteries discharge, the product phase formed in the cathode often contains two different morphologies, that is, crystalline and amorphous Li2O2. The morphology of Li2O2 impacts strongly on the electrochemical performance of Li–O2 cells in terms of energy efficiency and rate capability. Crystalline Li2O2 is readily available and its properties have been studied in depth for Li–O2 batteries. However, little is known about the amorphous Li2O2 because of its rarity in high purity. Herein, amorphous Li2O2 has been synthesized by a rapid reaction of tetramethylammonium superoxide and LiClO4 in solution, and its amorphous nature has been confirmed by a range of techniques. Compared with its crystalline siblings, amorphous Li2O2 demonstrates enhanced charge-transport properties and increased electro-oxidation kinetics, manifesting itself a desirable discharge phase for high-performance Li–O2 batteries.

ewebAMoq.title: What can we learn from the tension between PLANCK and BICEP2 data?
ewebAMoq.abstract: Recently BICEP2 collaboration has announced the detection of the primordial gravitational waves at high confidence level. In light of the results of B-modes power spectrum from BICEP2 and using the based ΛCDM, a constraint on the tensor-to-scalar ratio r = 0.20 −0.05 +0.07  (68% C.L.) can be obtained, however, this result is in apparent tension with the limit on standard inflation models from the recent PLANCK measurement, r < 0.11 (95% C.L.). Herein we review the recent progress on the cosmological studies after BICEP2 and discuss on different ways of reconciling the tension between PLANCK and BICEP2 data. We will discuss possible modifications on the standard cosmological model, such as including the running of scalar spectral index or other cosmological parameters correlated with inflationary cosmological parameters, or tilting the primordial power spectrum at large scales by introducing a cut off which can be predicted by bouncing cosmology. We will also comment on another possibility of generating extra B-modes of CMB polarization, namely by a non-zero polarization rotation angle during its transferring from the last scattering surface.

31w4ukpi.title: Probing the origin of our universe through primordial gravitational waves by Ali CMB project
31w4ukpi.abstract: Gravitational waves (GW), which were predicted by Einstein in 1916 based on the classical theory of General Relativity (GR), were recently detected by LIGO [1]. This breakthrough is expected to initiate a novel probe of cosmology, the nature of gravity as well as fundamental physics. In general, signals of GWs can be classified into two categories, which are waves from astro-physical and cosmological sources respectively. Accordingly, a number of astronomical and cosmological experiments are under design across the world [2]. In particular, China is playing a very important role in this field by strengthening a series of fundamental scientific subjects, such as cosmic evolution, structure of matter, the origin of life, cognition science, and so on, in the 13th National Five-Year Plan. The Ali project, which aims at measuring the polarization patterns of the cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation, was put forward in 2014 under the leadership of Xinmin Zhang’s group and has become very promising in exploring primordial GWs.

vQqO1Fri.title: A possible interpretation of the Higgs mass by the cosmological attractive relaxion
vQqO1Fri.abstract: Recently, a novel idea [1] has been proposed to relax the electroweak hierarchy problem through the cosmological inflation and the axion periotic potential. Here, we further assume that only the attractive inflation is needed to explain the light mass of the Higgs boson, where we do not need a specified periodic potential of the axion field. Attractive inflation during the early universe drives the Higgs boson mass from the large value in the early universe to the small value at present, where the Higgs mass is an evolving parameter of the Universe. Thus, the small Higgs mass can technically originate from the cosmological evolution rather than dynamical symmetry or anthropics. Further, we study the possible collider signals or constraints at a future lepton collier and the possible constraints from the muon anomalous magnetic moment. A concrete attractive relaxion model is also discussed, which is consistent with the data of Planck 2015.

S6ib61Px.title: Hearing the echoes of electroweak baryogenesis with gravitational wave detectors
S6ib61Px.abstract: We report on the first joint analysis of observational signatures from the electroweak baryogenesis in both gravitational wave (GW) detectors and particle colliders. With an effective extension of the Higgs sector in terms of the dimension-six operators, we derive a strong first-order phase transition associated with a sizable CP violation to realize a successful electroweak baryogenesis. We calculate the GW spectrum resulting from the bubble nucleation, plasma transportation, and magnetohydrodynamic turbulence of this process that occurred after the big bang and find that it yields GW signals testable with the Evolved Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, Deci-hertz Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory, and Big Bang Observer. We further identify collider signals from the same mechanism that are observable at the planning Circular Electron Positron Collider. Our analysis bridges astrophysics and cosmology with particle physics by providing significant motivation for searches for GW events peaking at the $(1{0}^{ensuremath{-}4},1)text{ }mathrm{Hz}$ range, which are associated with signals at colliders, and highlights the possibility of an interdisciplinary observational window into baryogenesis. The technique applied in analyzing early Universe phase transitions may enlighten the study of phase transitions in applied science.

ENYnJ3ye.title: Probing the gauge symmetry breaking of the early universe in 3-3-1 models and beyond by gravitational waves
ENYnJ3ye.abstract: Abstract   Taking the 3-3-1 models (with    S  U    (  3  )    c    ⊗  S  U    (  3  )    L    ⊗  U    (  1  )    Y      gauge group) as examples, we study that a class of new physics models with extended gauge group could undergo one or several first-order phase transitions associated with the spontaneously symmetry breaking processes during the evolution of the universe, which can produce detectable phase transition gravitational wave (GW) signals at future GW experiments, such as LISA, BBO, DECIGO, SKA and aLIGO. These GW signals can provide new sources of GWs with different peak frequencies, and can be used to probe the evolution history of the universe.

j92euLc5.title: Probing the nature of electroweak phase transition from particle colliders to gravitational wave detection

dN74nHdQ.title: Probing the hidden gauge symmetry breaking through the phase transition gravitational waves
dN74nHdQ.abstract: Motivated by the discovery of gravitational waves (GWs) and no evidence of new physics at current LHC, we discuss that many extended new physics models with hidden gauge group could undergo one or several times first-order phase transitions associated with the gauge group symmetry breaking in the evolution history of universe, which might produce detectable phase transition GWs signals at future GWs experiments, such as eLISA.

CpKtDFJo.title: Testing the electroweak phase transition in scalar extension models at lepton colliders
CpKtDFJo.abstract: We study the electroweak phase transition in three scalar extension models beyond the Standard Model. Assuming new scalars are decoupled at some heavy scale, we use the covariant derivative expansion method to derive all of the dimension-6 effective operators, whose coefficients are highly correlated in a specific model. We provide bounds to the complete set of dimension-6 operators by including the electroweak precision test and recent Higgs measurements. We find that the parameter space of strong first-order phase transitions (induced by the $|H|^6$ operator) can be probed extensively in $Zh$ production at future electron-positron colliders.

AHHqdvLZ.title: Testing the electroweak phase transition and electroweak baryogenesis at LHC and CEPC
AHHqdvLZ.abstract: We study the collider phenomenology of the electroweak phase transition and electroweak baryogenesis in the framework of the effective field theory. Our study shows that the effective theory using the dimension-6 operators can enforce strong first order phase transition and provide sizable CP violation to realize a successful electroweak baryogenesis. Such dimension-6 operators can induce interesting Higgs phenomenology that can be verified at colliders such as the LHC and the planning CEPC. We then demonstrate that this effective theory can originate from vector-like quarks and the triplet Higgs.

F0UUNKSK.title: Nonsingular Cosmology from an Unstable Higgs Field
F0UUNKSK.abstract: The observed value of the Higgs mass indicates an instability of the Higgs scalar at large energy scales, and hence also at large field values. In the context of early universe cosmology, this is often considered to lead to problems. Here, we point out that we can use the instability of the Higgs field to generate an ekpyrotic phase of contraction. In the context of string theory, it is possible that at very high energy densities, extra states become massless leading to an S-brane which causes the transition between a contracting phase in the past and the current expanding phase. Thus, the Higgs field may be useable to generate a nonsingular bouncing cosmology in which the anisotropy problem of usual bouncing scenarios is mitigated.

UgixFONe.abstract: We study the collider phenomenology of the electroweak phase transition and electroweak baryogenesis in the framework of the effective field theory. Our study shows that the effective theory using the dimension-6 operators can enforce strong first order phase transition and provide sizable CP violation to realize a successful electroweak baryogenesis. Such dimension-6 operators can induce interesting Higgs phenomenology that can be verified at colliders such as the LHC and the planning CEPC. We then demonstrate that this effective theory can originate from vector-like quarks and the triplet Higgs.

vQIzuCt6.title: Interpretations of the DAMPE electron data
vQIzuCt6.abstract: The DArk Matter Particle Explorer (DAMPE), a high energy cosmic ray and $gamma$-ray detector in space, has recently reported the new measurement of the total electron plus positron flux between 25 GeV and 4.6 TeV. A spectral softening at $sim0.9$ TeV and a tentative peak at $sim1.4$ TeV have been reported. We study the physical implications of the DAMPE data in this work. The presence of the spectral break significantly tightens the constraints on the model parameters to explain the electron/positron excesses. The spectral softening can either be explained by the maximum acceleration limits of electrons by astrophysical sources, or a breakdown of the common assumption of continuous distribution of electron sources at TeV energies in space and time. The tentive peak at $sim1.4$ TeV implies local sources of electrons/positrons with quasi-monochromatic injection spectrum. We find that the cold, ultra-relativistic $e^+e^-$ winds from pulsars may give rise to such a structure. The pulsar is requird to be middle-aged, relatively slowly-rotated, mildly magnetized, and isolated in a density cavity. The annihilation of DM particles ($m_{chi}sim1.5$ TeV) into $e^+e^-$ pairs in a nearby clump or an over-density region may also explain the data. In the DM scenario, the inferred clump mass (or density enhancement) is about $10^7-10^8$ M$_odot$ (or $17-35$ times of the canonical local density) assuming a thermal production cross section, which is relatively extreme compared with the expectation from numerical simulations. A moderate enhancement of the annihilation cross section via, e.g., the Sommerfeld mechanism or non-thermal production, is thus needed.

Lxr2PK4Y.title: Ideals of the Confucian School and Their Status Quo
Lxr2PK4Y.abstract: The classical academy had four functions:discussing the way of the world,transmitting knowledge,etiquette education,and editing and publishing books.The Confucian school always valued learning for oneself and character cultivating skills.It was believed that such knowledge was most relevant to oneself and depended on examining knowledge in relation to one's own practice to be able to bring about one's union with nature.Human beings play a double role of consumers and builders of society.The first role indicates the necessity of creating material wealth for society whereas the second role indicates the necessity of infusing a revolutionary spirit into society.According to Confucian beliefs,revolutions must be justified by heavenly order,and to minimize loss as a result of violence,conflicts must be resolved through non-violence in a just social system.Revolutions must be brought into the orbit of the right order and they must conform with the will of Heaven and meet the needs of society with regard to form and content.

authors.name: Zhang Xin-min
authors.org: Academy of Chinese Culture,Guizhou University,Guiyang,Guizhou

zMgOkGeV.title: Understand the Significance of Chinese Culture——A speech at anacademic forum between Chinese and American scholars
zMgOkGeV.abstract: This is a speech by the present writer at an academic forum held for the visiting group from St.Cloud State University.The paper states that Chinese culture has always attached great importance to protecting the dignity between man and man,and good advice and encouragement is a good example for that.The unification of the whole land for thousands of year in China is rather rare in other countries in the world.The experience and wisdom embodied in it is worth the attention of the people in the world today.Without it,the construction of the world civilization tomorrow will not be free from weaknesses and imperfection.East or West,every country should take in the successes in civilization construction into their own system for reference,so as to stimulate the creative change of the tradition based on mutual respect and reflection.Only when we give up self-centered strategy and carry out equal exchange and dialogue,the world could find out a model for harmonious development from the present interdependent multi-structured culture.

authors.name: ZHANG Xin-min
authors.org: The Institute of Chinese Culture,Guizhou University,Guiyang,Guizhou,,China

eUs9nSSc.title: Interpretation of the Traditional Symbolic Hermeneutics
eUs9nSSc.abstract: Taking into account the natural world and human world,the symbolic hermeneutics of "Heaven,Earth,the Ruler,the Parents and the Mentor" represents a complete order structure and value structure with multiple symbolic interpretation,receives the unanimous recognition of all tradition,reflects the development of Confucianism as a form of folk and the combination of Confucianism and daily experience,settles the daily life of Chinese people,and offers reasonable interpretation of political science,sociology,cultural anthropology.

authors.name: ZHANG Xin-min
authors.org: Guizhou University,Guiyang,,China

authors.name: JIANG Qing
authors.org: Yang Ming Academy,Guiyang,,China

IDxV3TJZ.title: The Text World of Local Knowledge——On the Compilation Headstream of Guizhou Chorography
IDxV3TJZ.abstract: The text particularizes the all parts of each developing period of Guizhou chorography from the Song Dynasty to the Republic of China by the means of distinguishing the academic genre and analyzing the academic headstream,considers that the origin of Guizhou chorography perhaps is traced back to Hua Yang Guo Zhi,and in due form appears in the Song Dynasty.Guizhou chorography went on developing in the Yuan Dynasty,was basically definitized in the Ming Dynasty,was advanced at which height of power and splendour in the Qing Dynasty,and appeared the new transformation in the Republic of China.A great deal of compilation of Guizhou chorography not only reflect historical character of traditional historiography firmly preserving the culture memory,but also build the text world of local knowledge.Besides the interior development rule of chorography itself,the intervening and impelling of administration rational force,the self-awakening of local culture consciousness and the value pursue of traditional scholar-bureaucrats by expounding their imperishable ideas in writing,all of which promote the development of aspiration career.As the local knowledge treasury,the chorogophic text content is wide-ranging,as long as the politics rising and falling,the culture eating and flowing,the economy ups and downs,and the people's livelihood standing or falling,all might be realized by investigating corresponding division into districts.

authors.name: ZHANG Xin-min
authors.org: Guizhou University,North School Region,Chinese Culture College,Guiyang,Guizhou ,China

A3zdziWJ.title: To Discover History in the Miao Areas:Preface to Turning Chieftains into Government Officials in Miao Area
A3zdziWJ.abstract: During the Yongzheng Era of the Qing Dynasty,exploitation and colonization were widely promoted in the Miao area,which was actually an re-order construction in the name of turning Miao chieftains into government officials.The Miao area,changed and reconstructed because of the royal enlightenment,had realized the national transformation process of turning the Barbarian Miao into Civilized Miao and Civilians and then Residents.It had also realized the interior inland transformation process from a Barbarian Area into a Civilized Area,from a frontier region into an interior area,accomplishing the state unification in a barbarian area.The study of the transformation process of the Miao area should apply as much as possible to the requirments of bifurcated history,paying attentions to the long-term complicated interactions between the state and the area.The re-discovery of the Miao history with the living and vivid local features can be positive to the establishment of a regional study descipline-the Study on the Qingshui River Valley.
keywords: the study on the Qingshui River Valley

f7l1NXR6.title: On the Outpouring of Writing Poetry from the Expression of Life——Preface to the Ren Bang Shan Zhai Can Gao
f7l1NXR6.abstract: Ren Bang Shan Zhai Can Gao includes the poetries,lot of which are wonderful sentences,and vent to the real aspirations,express the spirit,stir up one's feelings from the sign.It seems the spirits come to help the poet by the coming of an unexpected,however which originate in an expression of poet's experience with life,and which is indispensable for exquisite subtle description of life,actually.This is sufficient to show that the real poet is created out of the material of the human spirit.The sentences of poetry are the sublimation of art of poet's experience with life.
keywords: experiences of life the expression of spirit writing poetry sublimation of art

authors.name: Zhang XinMin
authors.org: The Chinese culture college,Guizhou University.

kbCCjh6I.title: The Research on The Pundit Sun Yingao and His Writings In Ming Dynasty:The Preface of Punctuation and Collation Combined Issue of Huaihai Yi Tan and Du Xue Corpus
kbCCjh6I.abstract: Sun Ying-ao was a learned scholar risen from the southwest region in his generation.He is another ideology and culture peak after the development of YangMing-school.Because a lot of his writings failed to be handed and were obscure,few important research production could be seen.So we search many historical materials in every ways,investigate ancient writings,clarify the outline of his writings and delve the direction and interestingness of his academic idea.At the same time we sort out and publish his writings by stages and in groups,eventually compile Sun Ying-ao's complete works.What we have done is not only beneficial to relocate and evaluate the contributions of academic culture of Wang Yang-ming's genre in the center area of Guizhou,but also restore the geographic distribution picture which highlights Wang Yangming's Mind Studies in the Ming dynasty.
keywords: The study on Confucius vihara collection
Wang Yang-ming's genre in the center area of Guizhou

authors.name: ZHANG Xin-min
authors.org: Academy of Chinese Culture,Guizhou University,Guiyang,Guizhou,,China

pFWlegu8.title: Diversified Spiritual Education Should Be Regarded as the First Principle of Education—Reply to the Modern Significance of the Traditional Idealistic
pFWlegu8.abstract: From the origin of the mind to understand and get hold of one's own,which means developing and creating oneself. Upstanding personality within the spirit needs the consciousness of inner spirit,and infinite power from the depth of life. Philosophy of mind should be regarded as the first meaning of philosophy,spiritual education is also necessary to be regarded as the first principle of education.

authors.name: ZHANG Xin-min
authors.org: Institute of Chinese Culture,Guizhou University,Guiyang ,China

8xE7X1lw.title: Xu Xiake and the Historical and Geographical Culture in Guizhou——An initial preface to Travel Notes in Qian
8xE7X1lw.abstract: Being a great and important person in the Chinese history,Xu Xiake traveled and adventured in Guizhou not for material gains,but for knowing the mysteries in this world.His journey was the process to temper his soul,cultivate his disposition,transcend worldly affairs,find the truth and upgrade his life.Reading between the lines,you will find the true feeling and temperament in Xu Xiake Travel Notes.Xu sought for the political pursuits all his life,yet he was still a Confucian intellectual.He exerted a pioneering influence on the study style in the late Ming and early Qing Dynasty.His travel in the southwest including Guizhou was always regarded as a pioneering experience by the esquire in the Central Plains.Xu Xiake Travel Notes is always given great attention to in the academic field.One important reason is that it fills up the blank in history in the southwest of China.
keywords: the study style in the Ming and Qing Dynasty

authors.name: ZHANG Xin-min
authors.org: The Chinese Academy of Ancient Learning,Guizhou University,Guiyang,Guizhou,,China

piOgr3yl.title: On the Collation and Utilization of Qingshui River Instruments and the——Form the"Explanation of Qingshuijiang Mstrumements"and Codified About
piOgr3yl.abstract: The characteristics of the holders of The Qingshui River Documents are very prominent,which could reflect the lives of both the original order and cultural order,and focus a large historical information relating to economic history, history of the land system,trade history of forestry and ethnic relations. The Qingshui River Documents actually are "live" document and not "dead" materials. On the one hand we could understand the concept of land rights,wealth,interests, market outlook,ethnic,marriage,Feng Shui and religion of local villagers from the Qingshui River Documents,on the other hand we also could draw conclusions that the traditional Chinese there is a wealth of civil and economic customary law as Western societies from which.

authors.name: ZHANG Xin-min
authors.org: The Chinese Culture College,Guizhou University,Guiyang,Guizhou ,China

q9zNkN4m.title: On the Li Su-Chang and GuYi Series
q9zNkN4m.abstract: The seven years of Guang XU (AD1881) ,during Li Su-chang took up the post of the Japan minister,with the help of his retinue Yang Shou-Jing,Li Su-chang searched for a lot of rare editions that were scattered and disappear in home but existed in Japan,and compiled the GuYi Series.the GuYi Series is received widespread recognition,and take on the typicalness significance of searching,arranging,compiling,and collating the literatures up to the present.The article collect the literature,search for the historical materials,detailedly discourse upon the idiographic experience of Li Su-Chang searching for the GuYi Series,and discuss reasons of spreading one by one,textual research true and false of the editions,distinguish the similarities and differences and the success and failure by the example of the Series of bibliotheca being in Japan,YuPian,WenGuanCiLin, XingJie,ShiLve,TaiPingHuanYuJi and so on.At the same time,the article corrects the error of modern people such as Yu Jia-xi,Zheng Tian-ting,etc.From the article we not only can realize the genuine value of GuYi Series, but also can transvalue the Li Su-chang's scientific attainments.

Iv1vA8fL.title: Jointly Promote the Development of Paleography and Local Philology:A Talk by Four on Cataloging and Research on the Literary Works in Qingshuijiang Region
Iv1vA8fL.abstract: The literary documents found in Qingshuijiang Region are the civil contract documents second largest in number to those found in Huizhou.The discovery has not only enriched or developed the materials to enhance our understanding of the civil rights and civil law system in China at that time,but also enriched or expanded study domain in the social and economic history from the Ming and the Qing Dynasty to the Republic of China;not only provided the evidences as a data source for multidisciplinary research,but also laid down the foundation for the international school of Qingshuijiang Studies.A serious and substantial study of how to catalog and how to understand the Qingshuijiang literary documents will demonstrate new achievements and new materials for the study of Chinese ancient philology but also tell us that there is a need to set up new programs for the fundamental studies of local philology.Scholars should be called for to carry out pioneering work for it.

PadjO4aH.title: Life Experience Structure and Music Phenomenology:the Preface of A Realm of Lucidity in Music
PadjO4aH.abstract: Music is a spiritual activity involving the interior world of a life main body,which is closely related to the human perception phenomenon and the experience structure,as well as the spiritual life.Only with a fine blend of personality,mind power,mood and music could real music activities occur.The richness of mood determines the colorfulness of music.The doctrine of neutralizations in Chinese culture is the resort of music,while the development of mood is,thereunder,the chronicle development of music.Ontologically,music-phenomenological activity is essentially display of the national spirit of an era.
keywords: A Realm of Lucidity in Music

Xbh0XK7b.title: The Profound Historical Influence of Wang Yangming's "Grasping the Truth" at Longchang:Investigating the Yangming School of Mind in Central Guizhou
Xbh0XK7b.abstract: Wang Yangming's "grasping the truth" at Nongchang was an event in the history of Chinese philosophical thinking that is worth commemorating. It is symbolic of Wang's triumph over the ordeals that had threatened his life and of a great leap-forward of his mind. Further,it heralded the birth of the earliest local school of mind in the country called the Yangming School of Mind in central Guizhou and ever since has exerted great influence on later philosophical thinkers in China and abroad. Indeed the emergence and development of the circle of native Guizhou philosophical thinkers is closely linked to Wang's preaching of his philosophy in central Guizhou. An abundance of discourse by generations of local scholars related to the school of mind has formed a continuous and distinctive body of values in interaction with knowledge.
keywords: scholarship in the Ming and Qing Dynasties
the Yangming School of Mind in central Guizhou

authors.name: Zhang Xin-min
authors.org: Academy of Chinese Culture,Guizhou University,Guiyang,Guizhou Prov.

1kUoTVIZ.title: Investigating the World of Qingshuijiang Documents and Qingshuijiang Civilization:Re-discussing the Construction of Qingshuijiang Study and Its Developmental Orientation for Research
1kUoTVIZ.abstract: The Qingshuijiang documents are actually of great value in the world memory cultural heritage.Together with Dunhuang Documents and Huizhou Documents,it can be regarded as one of the three great document systems.In line with the move of casting the material of the new money by virtue of mining copper mineral,collecting,collating and publicizing,we shall surely achieve success and create a prosperous academic situation with new materials and new themes.By broadening the areas of research and analysis,carrying out comprehensive cross studies,combining micro and macro views,contract documents and classic literature,field survey and desk work,that is,with a complementary approach(with different kinds of materials and different ways),we shall understand the world of Qingshuijiang documents and Qingshuijiang civilization better.We shall know the villagers and their life,know rural China,and in the end make Qingshuijiang Study an international branch of learning.

HtA37B4C.title: Luminescence of SrGdGa3O7:RE3+(RE = Eu, Tb) phosphors and energy transfer from Gd3+ to RE3+
HtA37B4C.abstract: Eu 3+ - and Tb 3+ -activated SrGdGa 3 O 7 phosphors were synthesized by the solid-state reaction and their luminescence properties were investigated. Sr(Gd 1 − x Eu x )Ga 3 O 7 and Sr(Gd 1 − x Tb x )Ga 3 O 7 formed continuous solid solution in the range of x = 0–1.0. Unactivated SrGdGa 3 O 7 exhibited a typical characteristic excitation and emission of Gd ion. The SrGdGa 3 O 7 : x Eu 3+ and SrGdGa 3 O 7 : x Tb 3+ phosphors also showed the well-known Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ excitation and emission. The energy transfer from Gd 3+ to Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ were verified by photoluminescence spectra. The dependence of photoluminescence intensity on Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ concentration were also studied in detail and the photoluminescence (PL) intensity of SrGdGa 3 O 7 :Eu and SrGdGa 3 O 7 :Tb were compared with commercial phosphors, Y 2 O 3 :Eu and LaPO 4 :Ce,Tb. The luminescence decay measurements showed that the lifetimes of Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ were in the range of microsecond. The energy transfer from Gd 3+ to Tb 3+ was also observed in decay curve. Keywords A. Optical material A. Oxides B. Chemical synthesis C. X-ray diffraction D. Luminescence 1 Introduction In recent years, great efforts have been made to develop new phosphor systems for white-LED, FED and PDP applications. Among these, a number of works have been carried out on investigation of the crystal chemistry and luminescent properties of compounds having melilite structure [1–8] . The general chemical formula AMM′ 3 O 7 (A = Ca, Sr, Ba; M = La, Gd, Y; M′ = Al, Ga) belongs to the large families that have melilite structure. Structural investigations indicate that they form tetragonal crystals with space group P 4 ¯ 2 1 m . The crystal structure is built up from layers of M′O 4 tetrahedra and between the layers the A 2+ and M 3+ ions are distributed randomly in site of C s symmetry. Many authors have reported the optical properties of these compounds [4–6,9–14] . However, there are few works that systematically investigated the photoluminescence (PL) properties of SrGdGa 3 O 7 doped with rare-earth ions. On the other hand, the lowest excited 4f level of Gd ( 6 P 7/2 ) gives rise to sharp line luminescence at about 313 nm and can sensitize the luminescence of other rare-earth ions. The energy levels of the CTS (charge-transfer state) and the 4f 6 5d 1 states are the highest among rare-earth ions, so that Gd 3+ serves as a good constituent cation in host crystals to be substituted by luminescent rare-earth ions [15] . So, we think that SrGdGa 3 O 7 might act as a potential host lattice for luminescence. This consideration prompted us to study the PL properties of this compound doped with rare-earth ions. In this present work, we report in detail the results of the PL properties, fluorescence decay lifetimes for Eu 3+ - and Tb 3+ -doped SrGdGa 3 O 7 phosphors. The energy transfer process from Gd 3+ to RE 3+ is also discussed. 2 Experimental Polycrystalline samples with the general formula Sr(Gd 1 − x Eu x )Ga 3 O 7 and Sr(Gd 1 − x Tb x )Ga 3 O 7 ( x = 0–1.0) were prepared by high temperature solid-state reaction. The starting materials were SrCO 3 (AR), Gd 2 O 3 (4N), Ga 2 O 3 (4N), Eu 2 O 3 (4N) and Tb 4 O 7 (4N). The raw materials were mixed homogeneously in an agate mortar and then fired at 1200–1400 °C for 24–36 h. The resulting powder samples were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD). The XRD patterns were recorded in the range 10° ≤ 2 θ ≤ 80° by using a Rigaku D/max 2200 Diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV, 30 mA. The PL emission and excitation spectra of polycrystalline phosphors were measured by a Hitachi F4500 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer and the decay curves of the Eu 3+ ion and Tb 3+ ion in SrGdGa 3 O 7 were measured by a FLS920-Combined Time Resolved & Steady State Fluorescence Spectrometer (Edinburgh Instruments). All the measurements were carried out at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase characterization The phase SrGdGa 3 O 7 has a tetragonal unit cell: a = 7.9651 Å and b = 5.2368 Å (JCPDS file: 50–1835). The crystal structure is built up from layers of GaO 4 tetrahedra and between the layers the Sr 2+ and Gd 3+ ions are distributed randomly in eight coordinated sites with C s symmetry. The selected X-ray diffraction patterns of Sr(Gd 1 − x Eu x )Ga 3 O 7 with x = 0–1.0 are shown in Fig. 1 . All of the peaks can be indexed to the SrGdGa 3 O 7 phase, indicating that the doping ions do not form new phases in the synthesis process. Moreover, the phases of SrGdGa 3 O 7 and SrEuGa 3 O 7 (JCPDS file: 50–1836) are iso-structure and continuous solid solutions form in the whole range ( x = 0–1.0) for the system Sr(Gd 1 − x Eu x )Ga 3 O 7 . On the other hand, the system Sr(Gd 1 − x Tb x )Ga 3 O 7 also forms continuous solid solutions in the whole range ( x = 0–1.0) according to the results of XRD patterns. Because the radius of Tb 3+ ( r Tb 3+ = 0.93 Å) is similar to that of Gd 3+ ( r Gd 3+ = 0.97 Å), it is not difficult to understand that the system Sr(Gd 1 − x Tb x )Ga 3 O 7 could form continuous solid solution. We also think that the phases of SrGdGa 3 O 7 and SrTbGa 3 O 7 are iso-structure according to the XRD patterns, and the detailed structure of SrTbGa 3 O 7 is worth investigating in the future. 3.2 Luminescence of unactivated SrGdGa 3 O 7 The excitation spectrum and emission spectrum of unactivated SrGdGa 3 O 7 are shown in Fig. 2 . All of the peaks exhibit well-known characteristic Gd 3+ excitations and emissions. An intense peak at 275 nm due to the 8 S 7/2 – 6 I 7/2 transition dominates the excitation spectrum. The other peaks due to the 8 S 7/2 – 6 D 7/2 and 8 S 7/2 – 6 D 9/2 transitions are also observed at 247 nm and 254 nm, respectively. The intense emission line at 313 nm is assigned to the 6 P 7/2 – 8 S 7/2 transition, whereas the weak peak at 307 nm is attributed to the 6 P 5/2 – 8 S 7/2 transition. 3.3 Luminescence of Eu 3+ -activated SrGdGa 3 O 7 Fig. 3 shows the PL spectra for SrGd 0.96 Ga 3 O 7 :0.04Eu 3+ . Close examination of the excitation spectrum ( Fig. 3 (a), λ em = 613 nm) reveals features due to both Gd and Eu. It shows broad bands with the maximum at about 266 nm, which can be attributed to the charge-transfer transition from O 2− to Eu 3+ . The peaks situated at 275 nm and 313 nm can be attributed to the 8 S 7/2 – 6 I 7/2 and 8 S 7/2 – 6 P 7/2 transitions of Gd 3+ , respectively, which indicates that the energy transfer from Gd 3+ to Eu 3+ happens. The excitation peak at 394 nm and 465 nm can be attributed to the 7 F 0 – 5 L 6 and 7 F 0 – 5 D 2 transitions of Eu 3+ , respectively, in addition to many other weak lines due to the various f–f transitions of Eu 3+ . The phosphors of Eu 3+ -activated SrGdGa 3 O 7 are found to exhibit a red emission under UV excitation. Fig. 3 (b) shows the PL emission spectra under 266 nm UV excitation. It can be seen from Fig. 3 (b) that the spectrum is dominated by the main lines at 613 nm due to the 5 D 0 – 7 F 2 transition and 585 nm due to the 5 D 0 – 7 F 1 transition. The peaks from 5 D 0 – 7 F 2 (electric-dipole transition) is stronger than that from 5 D 0 – 7 F 1 (magnetic-dipole transition), which indicates that Eu 3+ occupies the Gd site with no inversion symmetry. This result is in agreement with the crystal structure of this material. On the other hand, the spectra also show an emission peak at 575 nm that is attributed to the 5 D 0 – 7 F 0 transition. This transition is strictly forbidden when the crystal field is small and consequently there is no mixing between different J levels. The observation of this transition indicates that the crystal field in SrGdGa 3 O 7 :Eu 3+ is strong enough to cause significant mixing between the 7 F J multiplets, thereby relaxing the J selection rule. There are some weak peaks in the range of 500–570 nm, which are assigned to the 5 D 1 – 7 F J transitions. The dependence of PL intensities ( 5 D 0 – 7 F 2 transition of Eu 3+ , λ ex = 266 nm) on Eu 3+ concentration is shown in Fig. 4 . The PL intensity increases with Eu 3+ content increasing. It is not until the Eu 3+ concentration goes beyond x = 0.08 that the emission intensity begins to decrease. However, the PL intensity does not quench a lot even if x = 1.0. Compared with commercial phosphor Y 2 O 3 :Eu, the PL intensity of SrGdGa 3 O 7 :Eu is about 15% at optimized Eu 3+ concentration. 3.4 Luminescence of Tb 3+ -activated SrGdGa 3 O 7 The excitation spectrum of the Tb 3+ emission ( λ em = 543 nm) for Sr(Gd 0.95 Tb 0.05 )Ga 3 O 7 is shown in Fig. 5 (a) . It shows broad excitation band in the wavelength range 200–300 nm, which can be attributed to the transition 4f 8 –4f 7 5d 1 (f–d transition) of Tb 3+ . Besides the f–d transition, it shows two excitation peaks at 275 nm and 313 nm, which can be assigned to the transitions 8 S 7/2 – 6 I 7/2 and 8 S 7/2 – 6 P 7/2 of Gd 3+ , respectively. The excitation spectrum shows the sharp and intense Gd 3+ excitation lines pointing to an efficient energy transfer from Gd 3+ to Tb 3+ . The PL emission spectra ( λ ex = 235 nm) under different Tb 3+ concentrations are shown in Fig. 5 (b). It can be seen from Fig. 5 (b) that the phosphors with different Tb 3+ concentration exhibit well-known characteristic Tb 3+ emissions when excited into f–d transition. The peaks at 482 nm, 543 nm, 586 nm and 623 nm can be attributed to 5 D 4 – 7 F 6 , 5 D 4 – 7 F 5 , 5 D 4 – 7 F 4 and 5 D 4 – 7 F 3 transitions, respectively, and the peaks at 382 nm, 416 nm and 438 nm can be assigned to 5 D 3 – 7 F 6 , 5 D 3 – 7 F 5 and 5 D 3 – 7 F 4 transitions, respectively. The emission spectrum of Tb 3+ is strongly dependent on the Tb 3+ concentration. At lower Tb 3+ concentration (for example x = 0.001), the transitions from 5 D 3 to 7 F J are observed at the range of 350–470 nm. With an increasing of Tb 3+ content, the 5 D 3 – 7 F J transitions decrease gradually, while the 5 D 4 – 7 F J transition increases. When x Tb 3+ ≥ 0.2, the emission peaks of 5 D 3 – 7 F J disappear and only 5 D 4 – 7 F J transitions of Tb 3+ are observed. This phenomenon can be explained by the cross-relaxation between 5 D 3 and 5 D 4 . The variations of PL intensities ( 5 D 4 – 7 F 5 transition of Tb 3+ , λ ex = 235 nm) with different Tb 3+ concentration x are illustrated in Fig. 6 . We can see that the luminescent intensities have wide saturation ranges from x = 0.05 to x = 0.60, and then decrease gradually. Compared with commercial phosphor LaPO 4 :Ce,Tb, the PL intensity of SrGdGa 3 O 7 :Tb is about 10% at optimized Tb 3+ concentration. 3.5 The luminescence decay of Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ emission The decay curves of the 5 D 0 – 7 F 2 transition of Eu 3+ for Sr(Gd 0.995 Eu 0.005 )Ga 3 O 7 and 5 D 4 – 7 F 5 transition of Tb 3+ Sr(Gd 0.995 Tb 0.005 )Ga 3 O 7 were measured. According to our experimental results, either the charge transfer band of Eu 3+ ( λ ex = 256 nm) or the 8 S 7/2 – 6 I 7/2 transition of Gd 3+ ( λ ex = 275 nm) is excited, the two decay curves for Sr(Gd 0.995 Eu 0.005 )Ga 3 O 7 can be well fitted by single exponential equation: I ( t ) = I 0 + A exp(− t / τ ), where I and I 0 is the luminescence intensity, A the constant, t the time, τ the decay time for the exponential components. The τ extracted from the fitted curve is 1.13 ms for both of the two decay curves. Fig. 7 shows the decay curves of the 5 D 4 – 7 F 5 transition of Tb 3+ under different excitation. When the transition 4f 8 –4f 7 5d 1 (f–d transition) is excited, the decay curve is shown in Fig. 7 (a). It can also be fitted by single exponential equation and the value of τ is 2.3 ms. At room temperature measurement, we do not observe apparently that the Eu 3+ luminescence shows an initial slow rise phenomenon when the excitation wavelength is changed to 275 nm (viz. the position of the Gd 3+ in 8 S 7/2 – 6 I 7/2 transition). However, in the system of Sr(Gd 1 − x Tb x )Ga 3 O 7 , the Tb 3+ luminescence shows a slow rise when the excitation wavelength is changed to 275 nm, which is shown in Fig. 7 (b). This curve can be well fitted by the double exponential equation: I ( t ) = I 0 [exp(− t / τ 1 ) + A exp(− t / τ 2 )], where I and I 0 is the luminescence intensity, t the time, τ 1 the decay time, τ 2 the decay and/or rise time, A the ratio of the two parts of the function. When A < 0, the second term represents rising, and for A > 0, the second term represents a further decay. The result of the fitting is shown in Fig. 7 (c). The values of parameters are τ 1 = 1.93 ms (decay time), τ 2 = 0.66 ms (rise time) and A = −1.59. The initial slow rise is attributed to the finite transfer time involved in the Gd–Tb energy transfer process, which further testifies that there exists energy transfer from Gd to Tb. 4 Conclusion Sr(Gd 1 − x Eu x )Ga 3 O 7 and Sr(Gd 1 − x Tb x )Ga 3 O 7 formed continuous solid solution in the whole range of x = 0–1.0. The energy transfer from Gd 3+ to Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ were verified by studying the luminescent properties of SrGdGa 3 O 7 : x Eu 3+ and SrGdGa 3 O 7 : x Tb 3+ . Compared with the commercial phosphors (Y 2 O 3 :Eu, LaPO 4 :Ce,Tb), the PL intensity of SrGdGa 3 O 7 :Eu and SrGdGa 3 O 7 :Tb were about 15% and 10% at optimized Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ concentration, respectively. The Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ lifetime were in the order of microsecond, which were reasonable for the forbidden transition in Eu 3+ and Tb 3+ . The initial slow rise in decay curve further testified that there existed energy transfer from Gd to Tb. 4gNw2yzo.title: Luminescence properties of (Ca1−xSrx)Se:Eu2+ phosphors for white LEDs application
4gNw2yzo.abstract: Novel phosphors of Eu 2+ -doped (Ca 1− x Sr x )Se for the application of white light emitting diodes (LEDs) were prepared by conventional solid-state reaction. Diffuse reflection spectra of CaSe, SrSe, CaSe:Eu 2+ and SrSe:Eu 2+ were measured. The excitation spectra consisted of two broad bands and were consistent with the diffuse reflectance spectra. The emission band is due to the 4f 6 5d 1 →4f 7 transition of the Eu 2+ ion. With an increase in x , the emission band shifted to shorter wavelength and the reason was discussed. The fluorescence lifetimes of Eu 2+ in (Ca 1− x Sr x )Se:0.04Eu 2+ were also measured and the values were reasonable for the allowed transition 4f 6 5d 1 →4f 7 in Eu 2+ .

IcYfAyjN.title: Photoluminescence properties of Eu2+ doped Ba2ZnS3 phosphor for white light emitting diodes
IcYfAyjN.abstract: The synthesis and photoluminescence properties of novel Eu 2+ doped Ba 2 ZnS 3 phosphors for white light emitting diodes (LEDs) are reported. Diffuse reflection spectra of Ba 2 ZnS 3 host and synthesized phosphors have been measured. The excitation spectra of synthesized phosphors consist of three broad bands between 250 nm and 550 nm and are consistent with the diffuse reflectance spectra. The emission spectra show the characteristic 4f 6 5d 1 → 4f 7 transition of Eu 2+ ion and there exists efficient energy transfer from host to Eu 2+ ions when excited by 350-nm light. The dependence of emission spectra on temperature is also measured; the possible reasons applied to explain the experimental results are also discussed. The fluorescence lifetime of Eu 2+ in Ba 1.995 ZnS 3 :0.005Eu 2+ is measured and the values are 1.49 and 23.4 μs. Keywords Luminescence Phosphors Chalcogenide Europium White LEDs

WH7KcT6e.title: Luminescent properties of Eu2+-activated SrLaGa3S6O phosphor
WH7KcT6e.abstract: Novel phosphor of Eu 2+ -doped SrLaGa 3 S 6 O was prepared by solid-state reactions at 900 °C and H 2 S atmosphere. The excitation and emission spectra of this phosphor showed that all were broadband due to 4f 7 –4f 6 5d 1 transitions of Eu 2+ . The phosphors with different Eu 2+ concentrations presented yellowish-green luminescence for both UV and visible excitation (200–500 nm). The concentration quenching mechanism was verified as quadrupole–quadrupole interaction and the value of the critical transfer distance was calculated as 17 Å. The fluorescence lifetime of Eu 2+ was also measured. Keywords Phosphors Chemical synthesis X-ray diffraction Luminescence 1 Introduction Rare-earth ions-doped materials are good candidates for photonic sources. Divalent rare-earth ions Eu 2+ have the 4f 7 electronic configuration of the ground states and the 4f 6 5d 1 electronic configuration of the excited states. The broadband absorption and luminescence of Eu 2+ are due to 4f 7 –4f 6 5d 1 transitions and the emission of Eu 2+ is very strongly dependent on the host lattice and can occur from the ultraviolet to the red region of the electromagnetic spectrum. The 5d–4f transition of Eu 2+ is also spin and parity allowed and the lifetime is submicroseconds. In recent years, many investigations of the preparation and the crystal chemistry of melilite families have been performed [1–10] . At the same time, their properties have been widely studied. Laser emissions have been observed in SrLaGa 3 O 7 :Er crystal [11] and SrLaGa 3 O 7 :Cr 4+ , Mn 5+ [12] . Ryba-Romanowski et al. [13] have reported the optical properties of Sr X Ga 3 O 7 ( X = La, Gd) doped with Cr 4+ . Kubota and his co-workers have reported the luminescent properties of SrLaGa 3 O 7 crystals doped with Eu 3+ , Tb 3+ and Tm 3+ [14] . Malinowski et al. [15] have studied the spectroscopy properties of Dy 3+ -doped SrLaGa 3 O 7 crystals. Long-lasting phosphorescences have also been reported recently in CaYAl 3 O 7 :Ce 3+ (CYAM) [16,17] , CaYAl 3 O 7 :Eu 2+ , Dy 3+ [18] and CaGdAl 3 O 7 :Eu 2+ , Dy 3+ [18] melilite crystals. Flahaut and co-workers [19] have shown that the thiogallates M LaGa 3 S 7 ( M = Ca, Sr) and La 5/3 Ga 3 S 7 have the structure of melilite. Fouassier has investigated the luminescent properties of Er 3+ in M LaGa 3 S 7 ( M = Ca, Sr) [20] . Today, white light-emitting diodes (LEDs) are in high demand in solid-state lighting technology because of their most challenging application as a replacement for conventional incandescent and fluorescent lamps. Currently, we are investigating the chemistry of rare-earth metals with gallium chalcogenides to discover new materials for white LEDs. Presented here are the luminescence data for an oxysulfide doped with Eu 2+ (SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ ), which also has the melilite structure. To our best knowledge, this is the first report of a study of such an activator in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O host. 2 Experiment Polycrystalline SrLaGa 3 S 6 O: x Eu compounds were prepared by conventional solid-state reaction. The stoichiometric amounts of source materials SrCO 3 (AR), La 2 O 3 (4N), Ga 2 O 3 (4N) and Eu 2 O 3 (4N) were thoroughly mixed by grinding, and then sintered in H 2 S at 900 °C for 4 h. The phase purity of the as-prepared phosphors was investigated by X-ray powder diffraction spectroscopy (XRD). The XRD patterns were recorded in the range 10° < 2 θ <70° by using a Rigaku RINT220 Diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV, 30 mA. The photoluminescence (PL) emission and excitation spectra of polycrystalline phosphors was measured by a Hitachi F4500 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer and the decay curve of the 4f 6 5d 1 → 4f 7 transition of the Eu 2+ ion in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O were measured by a FLS920-Combined Time Resolved & Steady State Fluorescence Spectrometer (EDINBURGH INSTRUMENTS). All the measurements were carried out at room temperature. 3 Results and discussion The crystal structure of SrLaGa 3 S 6 O has recently been refined to be tetragonal, space group P 4 ¯ 2 1 m with a = 9.374 Å and c = 6.0893 Å [1] . The frames of the compounds are formed by five-membered rings constructed from [Ga(O/S) 4 ] 5− tetrahedral linked at each corner. The Sr 2+ ions and La 3+ ions are surrounded octahedrally by eight anions and are distributed randomly in sites of C s symmetry. The crystal structure of SrLaGa 3 S 6 O is shown in Fig. 1 [1] . The typical powder X-ray diffraction patterns of (Sr 1− x Eu x )LaGa 3 S 6 O with x = 0.0–1.0 are shown in Fig. 2 , which indicates that the doped Eu 2+ ions have little influence on the structure of luminescence materials. Most of the peaks are assigned to the phases of SrLaGa 3 S 6 O (JCPDS file: 39–561). Moreover continuous solid solutions form in the whole range. The calculated lattice parameters are shown in Table 1 . We think that the phases of SrLaGa 3 S 6 O and EuLaGa 3 S 6 O are iso-structural and the detailed structure of EuLaGa 3 S 6 O is under investigation. The excitation and emission spectra of Eu 2+ -doped SrLaGa 3 S 6 O phosphor with 0.10 mol Eu 2+ concentrations are shown in Fig. 3 . The excitation spectrum shows broad bands absorptions from UV to visible light in the range of 200–500 nm. So both UV and visible light could excite this phosphor. No differences are observed for the emission band shape and position for different excitation wavelengths ( λ ex = 275, 330, 400 and 460 nm) except for luminescent intensity. The PL emission spectrum under 460 nm light excitation exhibits a well-known characteristic Eu 2+ emission. The emission band is due to the 4f 6 5d 1 –4f 7 transition of the Eu 2+ ion. No other special emission peaks of Eu 3+ are observed in the spectra, which proves that Eu 3+ in the matrix crystals have been reduced to Eu 2+ completely. The maximum wavelength of the emission spectrum is situated at λ max = 540 nm and the full-width half-maximum (FWHM) is 52 nm. All of the phosphors present yellowish-green luminescence for both UV and visible excitation (200–500 nm). The fluorescence spectra of SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphors doped with various concentration of Eu 2+ ( x = 0.02–0.70) excited by 460 nm light are shown in Fig. 4 . The dependence of PL intensities of (Sr 1− x Eu x )LaGa 3 S 6 O on Eu 2+ content is shown in Fig. 5 . The PL intensity increases with Eu 2+ content increasing until a maximum intensity is reached, and then it decreases because of concentration quenching. When the value of x is about 0.10, the maximum of PL intensity occurs. While discussing the mechanism of energy transfer in phosphors, Blasse [21] has pointed out that if the activator is introduced solely on Z ion sites, χ c is the critical concentration, N the number of Z ions in the unit cell and V the volume of the unit cell, then there is on the average one activator ion per V / χ c N . The critical transfer distance ( R c ) is approximately equal to twice the radius of a sphere with this volume: (1) R c ≈ 2 3 V 4 π x c N 1 / 3 . By taking the experimental and analytic values of V , N and χ c (535.08 Å 3 , 2, 0.10, respectively), the critical transfer distance of Eu 2+ in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor is found to be about 17 Å. Non-radiative energy transfer between different Eu 2+ ions may occur by exchange interaction, radiation reabsorption or multipole–multipole interaction. Eu 2+ is an isolated emission center in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor. The 4f 7 –4f 6 5d 1 transition of Eu 2+ is allowed while exchange interaction is responsible for the energy transfer for forbidden transitions and typical critical distances are then about 5 Å [22] . This indicates that the mechanism of exchange interaction plays no role in energy transfer between Eu 2+ ions in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor. The mechanism of radiation reabsorption comes into effect only when there is broad overlap of the fluorescent spectra of the sensitizer and activator and in the view of the emission and excitation spectra of SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor is unlikely to be occurring in the case. Since the fluorescent mechanism of Eu 2+ in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor is the 4f–5d allowed electric-dipole transition, the process of energy transfer should be controlled by electric multipole–multipole interaction according to Dexter's theory [22] . If the energy transfer occurs between the same sorts of activators, the intensity of multipolar interaction can be determined from the change of the emission intensity from the emitting level which has the multipolar interaction. The emission intensity ( I ) per activator ion follows the equation [23,24] : (2) I / x = K 1 + β x Q / 3 − 1 Where χ is the activator concentration; Q = 6, 8 or 10 for dipole–dipole, dipole–quadrupole or quadrupole–quadrupole interaction, respectively; and K and β are constant for the same excitation condition for a given host crystal. Since the critical concentration of Eu 2+ has been determined as 10%, the dependence of the emission intensity of the SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor excited at 460 nm on the corresponding concentration of Eu 2+ which is not less than the critical concentration (10%) is determined (see Fig. 6 ). It can be seen from Fig. 6 that the dependence of log( I / χ Eu 2+ ) on log( χ Eu 2+ ) is linear and the line slope is −3.42. The value of Q can be calculated as 10.25, which is approximately equal to 10. It indicates that quadrupole–quadrupole interaction is the concentration quenching mechanism of Eu 2+ emission in the SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor. Fluorescence decay curve for the 4f 6 5d 1 → 4f 7 transition of the Eu 2+ ion in (Sr 0.96 Eu 0.04 )LaGa 3 S 6 O is shown in Fig. 7 . The decay curve can be well fitted by double exponential equation: I ( t ) = I 0 + A exp( −t / τ 1 ) + B exp( −t/τ 2 ), where I and I 0 is the luminescence intensity, A and B are constants, t is the time, τ 1 and τ 2 are the decay time for the exponential components, respectively. The τ 1 and τ 2 extracted from the fitted curve are 1.44 and 13.74 μs, respectively. 4 Conclusion Novel phosphor of Eu 2+ -doped SrLaGa 3 S 6 O was prepared by solid-state reactions at 900 °C and H 2 S atmosphere. The excitation and emission spectra of these phosphors show that all are broadband, which can be viewed as the typical emission of Eu 2+ ascribed to the 4f–5d transitions. All of the phosphors present yellowish-green luminescence for both UV and visible excitation in the range of 200–500 nm. Because of their broadband absorption in the region 380–480 nm, these phosphors meet the application requirements for GaN-based LEDs. The critical quenching concentration of Eu 2+ in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor is determined as 10%. According to the refinement results of lattice microstructure, the critical transfer distance is calculated to be about 17 Å. By the experimental and theoretical calculation, it is identified that the mechanism of concentration quenching of Eu 2+ in SrLaGa 3 S 6 O:Eu 2+ phosphor is quadrupole–quadrupole interaction. The fluorescence lifetime of the 4f 6 5d 1 → 4f 7 transition of the Eu 2+ ion in (Sr 0.96 Eu 0.04 )LaGa 3 S 6 O is measured. The fluorescence decay curve can be well fitted by double exponential equation and the τ 1 and τ 2 are 1.44 and 13.47 μs, respectively. 2PpbuCHc.title: Up-conversion properties in KGd2F7:Yb 3+/Er3+
2PpbuCHc.abstract: Infrared to visible up-conversion emissions in Yb3+-Er 3+ co-doped KGd2F7 samples excited at 980 nm are presented in this paper. Green (2H11/2, 4S3/2→4I15/2), red ( 4F9/2→4I15/2) and violet ( 2H9/2→4I15/2) emissions are observed under low pumping power, and the green emission is dominant. The dependences of these emissions as function of the pumping power intensities and the doped rare-earth ion concentrations are described. The results indicate that the green and red emission of Er3+ ion result from two-photon excitation processes, and the violet emission of Er3+ ion from three-photon processes. The most efficient composition for green emission is 2-4 mol% Er3+ and 10-20 mol% Yb3+ in synthesized samples. The mechanisms for explaining these up-conversion properties have been provided. © 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

PzKktRfS.title: Ga2S3:Eu2+: Phosphor for yellowish-green LED
PzKktRfS.abstract: Eu2+-activated Ga2S3 phosphors were synthesized by solid-state reaction and their luminescence properties were studied with diffuse reflection spectroscopy, excitation spectra, emission spectra and fluorescence lifetime. The parameters of LED manufactured with phosphors Ga2S3:Eu2+ were measured. The excitation spectra of these phosphors are broadband and can be matched with the emission wavelength of GaN chip.

KoHRz88s.title: Up-conversion properties in KGd2F7:Yb3+/Tm3+
KoHRz88s.abstract: The infrared to visible up-conversion emissions in Yb3+-Tm3+ co-doped KGd2P7 samples excited at 980 nm was reported. The observed up-conversion emissions include intense blue 1G4→3H6(482 nm) transition and other weak transitions: 1D2→3H6(367 nm), 1G4→3F4(651 nm) and 1G4→3H5(776 nm). The concentration quenching of Tm3+ or Yb3+ is obvious at higher concentration due to the cross-relaxation. The optimum doping levels are 10% Yb3+ and 0.2%-0.4% Tm3+ for blue emission. Power studies reveal that the blue emission of Tm3+ ion results from three-photon processes, which require three energy transfers from Yb3+ to excite Tm3+ from 3H6 to 1G4 in succession.

TdOY51JM.title: Mn2+-doped Ba2ZnS3 phosphor as a potential luminescent material for white LEDs
TdOY51JM.abstract: Mn 2+ -doped Ba 2 ZnS 3 phosphors for white light emitting diodes (LEDs) have been prepared by high temperature solid-state reaction and their photoluminescence properties are reported. Diffuse reflection spectra of Ba 2 ZnS 3 host and synthesized phosphors have been measured. The excitation spectrum extends a broad range of wavelength and is consistent with the diffuse reflectance spectra. The emission bands are due to 4 T 1 ( 4 G) → 6 A 1 ( 6 S) transition of the Mn 2+ ion and there exists efficient energy transfer from host to Mn 2+ ions. The dependence of emission wavelength on Mn 2+ concentration is studied. The decay curve of Mn 2+ ions luminescence in Ba 2 Zn 0.995 S 3 :0.005 Mn 2+ is also measured. Keywords Phosphors Solid-state reactions Optical properties Luminescence

MPIvOsX2.title: Up-conversion properties in KGd2F7:Yb3+/Er3+
MPIvOsX2.abstract: Infrared to visible up-conversion emissions in Yb 3+ –Er 3+ co-doped KGd 2 F 7 samples excited at 980 nm are presented in this paper. Green ( 2 H 11/2 , 4 S 3/2 → 4 I 15/2 ), red ( 4 F 9/2 → 4 I 15/2 ) and violet ( 2 H 9/2 → 4 I 15/2 ) emissions are observed under low pumping power, and the green emission is dominant. The dependences of these emissions as function of the pumping power intensities and the doped rare-earth ion concentrations are described. The results indicate that the green and red emission of Er 3+ ion result from two-photon excitation processes, and the violet emission of Er 3+ ion from three-photon processes. The most efficient composition for green emission is 2–4 mol% Er 3+ and 10–20 mol% Yb 3+ in synthesized samples. The mechanisms for explaining these up-conversion properties have been provided.

ftwkDhml.title: One-step synthesis and double emission (Ca1 + x - yEuy)Ga2S4 + x phosphor for white LEDs
ftwkDhml.abstract: (Ca1 + x - yEuy)Ga2S4 + x phosphors have been synthesized one step by solid state reaction. The photoluminescence excitation and emission spectra of phosphors have been studied; the influence of host composition and Eu2+ concentration on emission spectra has also been investigated. The emission spectrum consists of yellow emission at 550 nm and red emission at 650 nm. It also indicates that the excitation spectrum is a broadband and can be well matched with the emission of GaN chip. Combined these phosphors with 460 nm-emitting GaN chips, White LEDs have been fabricated. Their electroluminescence spectra have been measured under 20 mA forward-bias current. Their CIE chromaticity coordinates and color temperature indicate that (Ca1 + x - yEuy)Ga2S4 + x phosphors are promising phosphors for GaN-based white LEDs. © 2008 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

AZ6n240s.title: Synthesis and spectral properties of Eu2+-doped Sr(S1-xSex) phosphors for leds
AZ6n240s.abstract: Eu2+-activated Sr(S1-xSex) phosphors were synthesized by solid-state reaction at high temperature. XRD patterns indicated that the phosphors are of single phase; the relationship between lattice constant and compositional ratio x is linear, in which the Vegard's law holds. The excitation spectra are consistent with diffuse reflectance spectra, indicating that the energy absorbed by phosphor can be transferred to Eu2+ efficiently. The excitation spectra of these phosphors show broadband, extending from UV to visible light; and they can be matched with the emission wavelength of GaN chip well. The emission spectra exhibit characteristic 4f65d1→4f7 transition of Eu2+ ion. With increasing x the emission band shifted to shorter wavelength, which can be explained by the change in crystal field. The decay curve of fluorescence can be well fitted by double exponential equation, and the lifetime of Eu2+ is of the order of microsecond. The lifetimes are reasonable for the allowed 4f65d1→4f7 transition. The electroluminescence spectra of red LED manufactured with phosphors Sr(S1-xSex):Eu2+ were measured and the parameters of them were also measured. In a word, Sr(S1-xSex):Eu2+ are good phosphors for LED application.

vXnJvHgk.title: Photoluminescence and time-resolved luminescence spectroscopy of novel NaBa4(BO3)3:Tb3+ phosphor
vXnJvHgk.abstract: Research highlights ► The photoluminescence and time-resolved luminescence spectroscopy of novel NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 : x Tb 3+ phosphors have been investigated. ► The analysis of the decay curves indicates that the dipole–dipole interaction between Tb 3+ ions is found to be responsible for the cross-relaxation. ► The two exponential fitting on the curves of 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition indicates that the initial slow rise is attributed to the 5 D 3 → 5 D 4 cross-relaxation process. Abstract This paper reports the photoluminescence (PL) properties of Tb 3+ in NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 , as well as the time-resolved luminescence properties. The PL excitation spectrum exhibits intense f → f transition absorption; the PL emission spectrum shows the strongest 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 emission at 540 nm. The relative intensity of 5 D 3 emission is much weaker than that of 5 D 4 emission even in the samples with lower Tb 3+ concentration. The 5 D 3 → 5 D 4 cross-relaxation produces a marked increase in the 5 D 3 decay rate with increasing Tb 3+ concentrations and introduces a non-exponential component into the initial part of the decay. The dipole–dipole interaction is found to be responsible for the cross-relaxation. The decay curves of 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition exhibit an initial rise phenomenon. The two exponential fitting indicates that the initial slow rise is attributed to the 5 D 3 → 5 D 4 cross-relaxation process. Keywords Phosphors Solid state reactions Optical properties Luminescence Time-resolved optical spectroscopies 1 Introduction Recently, high quality phosphors have attracted more attention due to their practical application in the fields of display, X-ray screens, fluorescent lamps, solid state lighting, and so on [1–8] . Rare earth ions have been playing an important role in the phosphor materials due to their abundant emission colors based on their 4f–4f or 5d–4f transitions [9] . Among them, the emission spectrum of Tb 3+ ion often shows an intense line emission near 544 nm arising from the 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition [10–14] . So Tb 3+ activated “green” phosphors are combined with Eu 2+ activated blue phosphors and Eu 3+ activated red phosphors to provide “trichromatic” lighting technology, a high-efficiency white light for standard illumination uses in indoor lighting [15] . Borates are good matrix for rare earth ions activated phosphors due to their low synthesis temperature, easy preparation and high luminescence efficiency [3,16–19] . The stoichiometric formula of borates MM′ 4 (BO 3 ) 3 (where M = Li + , Na + or K + and M′ = Ca 2+ , Sr 2+ or Ba 2+ ) have been reported by Wu et al. MM’ 4 (BO 3 ) 3 belongs to orthorhombic or cubic structure depending on the kind of cations [20,21] . Recently, these kinds of compounds attract more attention due to their potential application [3,20,21] . However, the PL properties of Tb 3+ in these matrixes have not been reported. In this paper, the NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 : x Tb 3+ phosphors have been prepared by solid-state reaction, and the PL and time-resolved luminescence properties were also investigated in detail. 2 Experimental NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 : x Tb 3+ samples were prepared according to the standard solid-state technique [21] . High-purity starting materials Na 2 CO 3 (Aldrich, 99.9%), BaCO 3 (Aldrich, 99.9%), H 3 BO 3 (Aldrich, 99.9%), and Tb 4 O 7 (Aldrich, 99.99%) were used. The well mixed materials were annealed at 700 °C for 12 h in CO weak reducing atmosphere with an intermediate grinding. Na + was added as a charge compensator. The structural characteristics of samples were checked by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns using a Philips XPert/MPD diffraction system with Cu Kα ( λ = 0.154 05 nm) radiation. All the samples are single phase. The PL emission and excitation spectra were measured by Fluorolog-3 Fluorescence Spectrophotometer with 450 W Xenon lamps. The luminescence decays were measured by monitoring the given emission from the samples under 266 nm pulsed laser excitation. Decay profiles were recorded by the 500 MHz digital oscilloscope (LeCroy 9350A) in which the signal was fed from PMT. 3 Results and discussion The PL emission and excitation spectra of NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 :0.10Tb 3+ phosphor are shown in Fig. 1 . The sharp excitation lines at 317, 350, 370, 377, and 485 nm are observed from the excitation spectrum of the 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition. These excitation lines can be ascribed to the transitions from 7 F 6 to 5 D J , 5 G J , 5 L 10 , 5 D 3 , and 5 D 4 , respectively. The excitation band near 300 nm could be ascribed to the Tb 3+ 4f 8 → 4f 7 5d 1 transition. In addition, NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 : x Tb 3+ phosphors show intense f → f transition absorption, which may be attributed to the uneven components mix a small amount of opposite parity wave functions (e.g., 5d) into the 4f wave functions; so the parity selection rule is relaxed [9] . Tb 3+ ion with 4f 8 configuration has complicated energy levels, so luminescence spectrum consisting of many lines due to 5 D J → 7 F J’ is observed. The emission spectrum of the NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 :0.10Tb 3+ sample under 375 nm UV excitation shows the 5 D 3 → 7 F J as well as the 5 D 4 → 7 F J emission lines. Among the emission lines, the 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 emission line at about 540 nm is the strongest one. The reason is that this transition has the largest probability for both electric-dipole and magnetic-dipole induced transitions [15] . However, the relative intensity of 5 D 3 emission is much weaker than that of 5 D 4 emission even in the sample with lower Tb 3+ concentration (0.1 mol%). It is well known that the intensity ratio of the emission from 5 D 3 to that from 5 D 4 depends not only on the Tb 3+ concentration [22–24] , but also on the host material [15] . In borate hosts, the relative intensity of 5 D 3 emission is much weaker than that in other hosts, such as phosphates, silicates, and aluminates [25–27] , which maybe have a relation to the energy of phonons [15] . The Tb 3+ concentration dependence on intensity of 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition has also been investigated. The intensity increases with increasing Tb 3+ concentration, and the concentration quenching does not take place even if Tb 3+ concentration x is equal to 10 mol% (i.e., NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 :0.10Tb 3+ ). Fig. 2 depicts the decay curves of 5 D 3 → 7 F 5 transition of Tb 3+ under excitation at 266 nm laser light. For the lower concentration ( x = 0.005), the decay is nearly exponential with a time constant of about 35 μs. As Tb 3+ concentration increases, the initial part of the curves becomes non-exponential and the time constants decrease gradually ( τ = 22 μs for x = 0.10). The possible reason could be that the 5 D 3 → 5 D 4 cross-relaxation produces a marked increase in the 5 D 3 decay rate with increasing Tb 3+ concentrations and introduces a non-exponential component into the initial part of the decay [28] . For the decay of 5 D J → 7 F J transition, the rigorous migration effect is found in the 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 decay, whereas no energy migration could be found in the 5 D 3 → 7 F 5 decay [29] . So energy migration can be neglected. In order to determine the interactions responsible for the non-radiative relaxation from the 5 D 3 level, the decay analysis of 5 D 3 → 7 F 5 transition can be carried out on employing the direct energy transfer based on the well known Inokuti–Hirayama model [30] . (1) I ( t ) I 0 = exp − t τ 0 − C C 0 Γ 1 − 3 S t τ 0 3 S where τ 0 is the radiative lifetime of an isolated excited Tb 3+ ion, Γ (1 − 3/ S ) is Euler's gamma function, C is acceptor ion concentration, C 0 is critical concentration defined as 3 / ( 4 π R 0 3 ) and S is the multipole interaction parameter. Many papers have reported that a dipole–dipole interaction is found to be responsible for the cross-relaxation at room temperature [28,29,31,32] . In the case of dipole–dipole interaction, the value of S is 6, and Γ (1 − 3/ S ) = 1.77. The fit of the decay curves of NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 : x Tb 3+ samples regarding dipole-dipole interaction indicates that the best agreement between experimental data and theoretical fits is obtained. The fitted results of NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 : x Tb 3+ ( x = 0.01, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.08 and 0.10) samples are given in Table 1 . The τ 0 value is about 70 μs for 5 D 3 → 7 F 5 transition of isolated Tb 3+ ions in NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 :Tb 3+ . The critical distance for the d–d interaction is found to be about 10 Å. The decay curves of 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition of Tb 3+ under excitation at 266 nm pulsed laser are represented in Fig. 3 . It can be seen that the decay curves show a nearly single exponential decay and does not vary obviously with increasing Tb 3+ concentration. A single exponential fit yields a decay time 1.9 ms. The lifetimes of 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition do not change indicating that concentration quenching does not happen within the range of Tb 3+ contents. Hao et al. has also observed similar phenomenon in CaSc 2 O 4 :Tb 3+ phosphor [24] . Moreover, it is noted that the decay curves of 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition exhibit an initial rise phenomenon (marked with red circle in Fig. 3 ). We attempted to fit these curves with double exponential equation [22,33] : (2) I ( t ) = I 0 exp − t τ 1 + A exp − t τ 2 where I and I 0 is the luminescence intensity, t is the time, τ 1 is a decay time, τ 2 is a decay and/or rise time, A is the ratio of the two parts of the function. When A < 0, the second term represents rising, and for A > 0, the second term represents a further decay. The results of the fitting indicate that the best agreement between experimental data and theoretical fits is obtained. The result of NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 :0.005Tb 3+ sample is shown in Fig. 4 . The values of parameters are τ 1 = 1.89 ms (decay time), τ 2 = 40 μs (rise time) and A = −0.7833. The initial slow rise with initial intensity (40%) of the 5 D 4 emission is due to the feeding process of the 5 D 4 population. It is fed about 40% of the 5 D 4 population from nearby Tb 3+ ions through the fast cross-relaxation process between Tb 3+ ( 5 D 4 → 5 D 3 ) and Tb 3+ ( 7 F 6 → 7 F 0 ) [32] . On the other hand, 60% of 5 D 4 population comes directly by non-radiative relaxation process from the 5 D 3 level having decay time of about 40 μs corresponding to the rise time of the 5 D 4 level. 4 Conclusions In NaBa 4 (BO 3 ) 3 : x Tb 3+ , the intense f → f transition absorption is observed comparing with the major Tb-doped phosphors; the 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition at 540 nm is the strongest emission, and the relative intensity of 5 D 3 emission is much weaker than that of 5 D 4 emission even in the sample with lower Tb 3+ concentration. The decay curves of 5 D 3 → 7 F 5 transition can be well fitted by Inokuti–Hirayama model, and the dipole-dipole interaction is responsible for the cross-relaxation. The derived critical distance for the d–d interaction is 10 Å. The decay curves of 5 D 4 → 7 F 5 transition can be fitted by double exponential function, indicating that the initial slow rise with 40% of initial intensity of the 5 D 4 emission is attributed to the feedings from higher energy levels and the cross-relaxation process between two Tb 3+ ions. OAHOFkTh.title: Red emission LaMoBO6: Eu3+ phosphor for near-UV white light-emitting diodes
OAHOFkTh.abstract: Red emission LaMoBO6: Eu3+ phosphors were synthesized by solid-state reaction, and their photoluminescence properties were investigated for the first time. The results indicate that LaMoBO6: Eu3+ phosphors have many advantages, such as lower synthesis temperature, strong absorption in the near-UV region, and excellent chromaticity coordinates. La1-x MoBO6:x Eu3+ phosphors are promising candidates for phosphor-converted white light-emitting diodes. © 2010 The Electrochemical Society.

BBAK8bVf.title: Novel blue-emitting Sr3Ga2O5Cl2:Eu2+ phosphor for UV-pumped white LEDs
BBAK8bVf.abstract: A novel blue-emitting Sr3Ga2O5Cl2:Eu2+ phosphor has been synthesized by a two-step solid-state reaction. The luminescence properties have been investigated by photoluminescence (PL) spectra, and temperature-dependent PL spectra. It shows an efficient broad absorption band around 400 nm, which matches well with the commercial near-ultraviolet light-emitting chips, and an efficient blue emission. It shows a higher thermal quenching temperature than that of Sr3Al2O5Cl2:Eu2+ phosphor. Sr3Ga2O5Cl2:Eu2+ phosphor is a promising blue-emitting component for UV chip excited white light-emitting-diodes. © 2010 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

l2f9lc1n.title: Eu2+–Mn2+ energy transfer in white-light-emitting T-phase (Ba,Ca)2SiO4:Eu2+, Mn2+ phosphor
l2f9lc1n.abstract: White-light-emitting T-phase Eu2+/Mn2+-codoped (Ba, Ca)2SiO4 phosphors are achieved in terms of the energy transfer between Eu2+ and Mn2+ ions. All spectra consist of the relatively broad green and the red emission bands, which thus result in a warm-white color with a color temperature of ∼4000 K. With increasing Eu2+ ions at fixed Mn2+ concentrations, a strong correlation between the luminescence and the electron paramagnetic resonance spectra is observed. This demonstrates that Eu2+ doping causes a perturbation of Mn2+ sites and the violation of their selection rules that enhances Mn2+-related emissions. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

fk9TjSI6.title: On the luminescence of Ce 3+, Eu 3+, and Tb 3+ in novel borate LiSr 4(BO 3) 3
fk9TjSI6.abstract: This paper reports on the photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved properties of Ce 3+, Eu 3+, and Tb 3+ in novel LiSr 4(BO 3) 3 powder phosphors. Ce 3+ shows an emission band peaking at 420 nm under 350-nm UV excitation. Energy transfer from Ce 3+ to Mn2+ takes place in the co-doped samples. Eu 3+ shows red emission under near UV excitation. LiSr 4(BO 3) 3:Eu 3+ phosphor could be a suitable candidate for phosphor-converted solid state lighting. The luminescence lifetime is 2.13 ms for Eu 3+ in LiSr 4(BO 3) 3:0.001Eu 3+. As Eu 3+ concentration increasing, the decay curves deviate from exponential behavior. Tb 3+ shows the strongest 5D 4→ 7F 5 emission line at 540 nm. Decay curves of 5D 4→ 7F 5 and 5D 3→ 7F 5 emission with different Tb 3+ concentrations were also measured. Cross-relaxation process is discussed based on the decay curves. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2011.
